claim: Cage-free hens can roam outdoors and have access to the outdoors.

supporting.text: Cage-free hens are not confined to cages and are allowed to move freely within a barn or enclosed area.

attacks.text: Cage-free hens are not confined to cages and are allowed to move freely within a barn or enclosed area.
Cage-free does not necessarily mean outdoor access; many cage-free hens are still confined indoors without outdoor access.
Industry standards for 'cage-free' often include provisions for outdoor access or enriched environments, even if not all farms implement it.
The term 'cage-free' is often misleading, as hens may still be densely packed in barns with limited space to roam.
Certification programs like 'Certified Humane' or 'Free Range' ensure stricter standards for space and outdoor access than basic 'cage-free' labels.

supporting.text: Access to the outdoors is not guaranteed for all cage-free hens, as some systems may only provide indoor space.

attacks.text: Access to the outdoors is not guaranteed for all cage-free hens, as some systems may only provide indoor space.
Many cage-free certifications explicitly require outdoor access, ensuring compliance for certified producers.
Certification standards vary by region, and some allow 'cage-free' labeling without mandating outdoor access.
Consumer demand increasingly pressures farms to provide genuine outdoor access, even beyond certification requirements.
Economic constraints often lead farms to prioritize cost-saving indoor systems despite consumer preferences.

supporting.text: The term 'cage-free' does not necessarily imply outdoor access, as it primarily indicates the absence of cages.

attacks.text: The term 'cage-free' does not necessarily imply outdoor access, as it primarily indicates the absence of cages.
Many cage-free certifications, such as 'Certified Humane,' explicitly require outdoor access or pasture time.
Even within certifications, enforcement of outdoor access requirements can be inconsistent or loosely regulated.
Consumer perception often conflates 'cage-free' with outdoor access, regardless of formal definitions.
Marketing materials for cage-free products frequently emphasize outdoor imagery, reinforcing this misconception.

supporting.text: Some cage-free systems include outdoor access as part of their animal welfare standards.

attacks.text: Some cage-free systems include outdoor access as part of their animal welfare standards.
Many cage-free systems still restrict outdoor access due to biosecurity concerns or limited space.
Even when outdoor access is provided, it may be minimal or impractical, such as small porches or screened areas.
The term 'cage-free' does not legally require outdoor access in many jurisdictions, leading to misleading labeling.
Consumer awareness campaigns and stricter regulations are improving transparency in labeling cage-free systems.

supporting.text: Regulations for 'cage-free' labeling vary by region and do not universally require outdoor access.

attacks.text: Regulations for 'cage-free' labeling vary by region and do not universally require outdoor access.
Many major certification programs, such as Certified Humane, do require outdoor access for cage-free hens.
Even with certification programs, enforcement of outdoor access requirements is inconsistent and often poorly monitored.
Consumer perception of 'cage-free' often assumes outdoor access, regardless of regional regulatory differences.
Marketing and labeling practices exploit this perception without guaranteeing actual outdoor access.

supporting.text: Outdoor access for cage-free hens depends on farm-specific practices and may be limited by weather or predator protection.

attacks.text: Outdoor access for cage-free hens depends on farm-specific practices and may be limited by weather or predator protection.
Many cage-free farms implement strict outdoor access policies to ensure animal welfare standards are met regardless of weather or predator risks.
Even with policies in place, unpredictable weather or predator threats can still force farms to temporarily restrict outdoor access, undermining consistent freedom.
Certification programs like Certified Humane require verifiable outdoor access, reducing variability in farm practices.
Certification standards often allow for loopholes or exceptions, such as 'porches' counting as outdoor access, which may not meet consumer expectations.
